summary.en: In this paper I seek to challenge the notion of a significant or relevant ¿other¿ in the creation and maintenance of boundary mechanisms within theories of ethnicity and nationalism during conflict and war. My contention is that the notion of a significant other related to ethnic and national boundary mechanisms during war-time has generally been viewed from macro level with a  ¿top-down¿ approach, and has thus been too much influenced by the production of ¿formal¿ nationalism (or ethno-nationalism) (Eriksen 1993), blurring the actual empirical processes on the ground. Hence, the notion of a significant other is portrayed as a singularly understood, commonly perceived concept by all the members of the in-group. This is a simplification which, according to my understanding, overlooks the individual creation of selfhood and the multivocal capacity in the symbolic production of ethnicity and nationalism, a capacity which is increased during conflict and war due to the grave impact of violence which permeates all aspects of everyday life.

title.en: ¿You see our physical bodies only, but they are mere containers. We are as living dead!¿: Conceptualising the experiences of violence and the negotiation of identities in Tigray, Ethiopia

event.name: Conflict's Fruit: Poverty, Violence and the Politics of Identity in African Arenas
